title: 111_s1520
content: CHAPTER 1504 - NATIONAL AMERICAN INDIAN VETERANS, INCORPORATED: This section recognizes National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated as a corporation and grants them a federal charter under Part B of subtitle II of title 36, United States Code. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation in the United States. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation in the United States with purposes that include upholding and defending the Constitution while respecting the sovereignty of American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian Nations. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated aims to unite American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans under one body and advocate for them regardless of when they served. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated aims to unite American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans under one body, advocate for them regardless of when they served, and promote social welfare in the United States. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated aims to promote social welfare by encouraging the growth and development of American Indian veterans, advocating for their needs, and supporting research on their relationship with the government. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated aims to advocate for the needs of American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans, support research on their relationship with American society, and provide technical assistance to regional areas without veterans committees or organizations. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated aims to advocate for the needs of American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans, support research on their relationship with American society, and provide technical assistance to regional areas without veterans committees or organizations. Membership eligibility and rights are determined by the corporation's constitution and by-laws. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated advocates for American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans. Membership eligibility and rights are determined by the corporation's constitution and by-laws. The corporation provides training for Tribal Veterans Service Officers and outlines the responsibilities of the board of directors and officers. The board of directors and officers of the corporation are determined by its constitution and bylaws, in accordance with the laws of incorporation. Membership conditions are established without discrimination. The officers of the corporation and their election are determined by the constitution, bylaws, and laws of incorporation. Membership and board requirements cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, handicap, or age. The corporation is granted specific powers. The corporation cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, handicap, or age in membership and board requirements. The corporation's powers are limited to those granted in its articles of incorporation and bylaws, conforming to the jurisdiction's laws. The corporation's powers are limited to those granted in its articles of incorporation and bylaws, conforming to the jurisdiction's laws. It has the exclusive right to use specific names, seals, emblems, and badges. The corporation has the exclusive right to use specific names, seals, emblems, and badges. It is restricted from issuing stock, paying dividends, or distributing income or assets to members. The corporation is restricted from issuing stock, paying dividends, or distributing income or assets to members. Officers may receive reasonable compensation and reimbursement for expenses approved by the board of directors. The corporation is prohibited from making loans to any officer, director, member, or employee. It cannot claim congressional approval or Federal Government authority for its activities. Officers may receive reasonable compensation and reimbursement for expenses approved by the board of directors. The corporation is prohibited from making loans to any officer, director, member, or employee and cannot claim congressional approval or Federal Government authority. It must maintain its tax-exempt status and keep correct and complete records. The corporation must maintain its tax-exempt status as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It is required to keep accurate records of accounts, meeting minutes, and member information at its principal office. The corporation must maintain tax-exempt status as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by keeping accurate records of accounts, meeting minutes, and member information at its principal office. Members have the right to inspect all books and records for any proper purpose at any reasonable time. The corporation's books and records can be inspected by members with voting rights or their agents for any proper purpose at a reasonable time. This does not override the laws of the jurisdiction where the corporation is incorporated or operates. The corporation must comply with jurisdictional laws regarding service of process. The corporation must comply with jurisdictional laws for service of process and liability for acts of officers and agents within the jurisdictions where it operates. The corporation is liable for the acts of its officers and agents when they act within their authority. Failure to comply with the chapter's restrictions will result in the expiration of the charter. An annual report is required. The corporation is liable for the acts of its officers and agents within their authority. Failure to comply with chapter restrictions will lead to charter expiration. An annual report to Congress on the corporation's activities is mandatory. The corporation must provide an annual report to Congress on its activities, which is due at the same time as the audit report. The annual report is not made public.
